text: Sara Mae Berman (née Sidore born 14 May 1936) is an American marathon runner. Berman won the Boston Marathon as an unofficial winner from 1969 to 1971 as women were not allowed to compete until 1972. At subsequent Boston Marathons, Berman had a fifth place finish in both 1972 and 1973. Berman's wins were made official by the Boston Athletic Association in 1996. Outside of Boston, Berman finished third at the 1971 New York City Marathon. In 2015, she was inducted into the Road Runners Club of America Hall of Fame. == Early life and education == Berman was born on 14 May 1936 in The Bronx, New York City. She spent her childhood in New Hampshire and graduated from the Rhode Island School of Design with a Bachelor of Fine Arts in 1958. == Career == Berman began her distance running career in 1964 at a five-mile road race in Marlborough, Massachusetts. From 1969 to 1971, she won the Boston Marathon while setting a course record in the 1970 Boston Marathon of 3:05:08. At the 1972 Boston Marathon, she finished fifth in the first sanctioned women's event. At the following Boston edition, Berman had another fifth place finish at the 1973 Boston Marathon. After Berman did not appear at Boston between 1974 to 1976, Berman competed at her final Boston events from 1977 to 1979. Berman's wins from 1969 to 1971 were unofficial as the Boston Marathon was not open to women until 1972. In 1996, her Boston Marathon wins were made official by the Boston Athletic Association. Apart from Boston, Berman was third at the 1971 New York City Marathon. She retired from running in 2000. Outside of marathon running, Berman participates in ski-orienteering and cross-country skiing. Berman and her husband founded the Cambridge Sports Union in 1962 and were publishers of Orienteering North America magazine from 1985 to 1999. ==Achievements== {| |- !colspan="6"|Representing |- |1969 |Boston Marathon |Boston, United States |bgcolor="gold" | 1st |Marathon |3:22:46 |- |1970 |Boston Marathon |Boston, United States |bgcolor="gold" | 1st |Marathon |3:05:07 |- |1971 |Boston Marathon |Boston, United States |bgcolor="gold" | 1st |Marathon |3:08:30 |- |1972 |Boston Marathon |Boston, United States |5th |Marathon |3:48:30 |- |} == Awards and honors == In 2013, Berman was selected alongside Bobbi Gibb as the 2013 Boston Marathon's Grand Marshals. In 2015, Berman was inducted into the Road Runners Club of America Hall of Fame. == Personal life == By 1964, Berman is married and has three children. == References == Category:1936 births Category:Boston Marathon female winners Category:American female marathon runners Category:Living people Category:American female long-distance runners Category:Track and field athletes from New York (state) Category:Sportspeople from the Bronx
